channel.title: Turning off the GUI in Ubuntu Home
channel.description:
How do I temporarily turn it off so ubuntu runs with the usual services, but boots straight into a command prompt instead of loading up the gui each time. Can it be turned back on (or off again) by a command without having to reinstall/uninstall it incase I need the ui to do something I wouldn't know how to do with commands?
I'm going to install ubuntu server edition instead when I replace the hard disks with new ones in a few months, I just don't want the downtime now because I'm new to linux and could take me days to set it up.

item.title: Turning off the GUI in Ubuntu Home
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

Besides, what does anyone ever hit that combo for if they don’t want to restart X? I never used that combo in windows that I remember.

Read full topic

[/quote]

It is in the latest version, and I agree with Speljohan 100% on that one, fucking stupid.[/quote]
+1, CTRL-ALT-BKSPCE is a Linux pastime.

item.title: Turning off the GUI in Ubuntu Home
item.dc:creator: @Unhandled Unhandled
item.description:
@Unhandled wrote:

[quote=“Creme de la Creme, post:13, topic:273767”][quote author=Moparisthebest link=topic=361786.msg2756545#msg2756545 date=1240248693]
Did you try holding down alt and pressing F1 through F6 to get to another terminal?
[/quote]Yeh people at ubuntu forums told me to try that, I never knew there were different terminals. For whatever reason the terminal it boots in doesn’t allow access as though its idling for something like the shutdown command.

Never asked at ubuntu because it wasn’t a big issue, but pressing ALT+F7 does nothing. Shouldn’t that be terminal 7? T1,2,3,4,5,6,8 all work.[/quote]
“Terminal 7” is the terminal X runs on by default.

Read full topic

item.description:

[quote=“Moparisthebest, post:12, topic:273767”]Did you try holding down alt and pressing F1 through F6 to get to another terminal?[/quote]Yeh people at ubuntu forums told me to try that, I never knew there were different terminals. For whatever reason the terminal it boots in doesn’t allow access as though its idling for something like the shutdown command.

Never asked at ubuntu because it wasn’t a big issue, but pressing ALT+F7 does nothing. Shouldn’t that be terminal 7? T1,2,3,4,5,6,8 all work.

(brb making ubuntuforums.com advert)

item.dc:creator: @Speljohan Speljohan
item.description:
@Speljohan wrote:

[quote=“Creme de la Creme, post:7, topic:273767”][quote author=Fat Cookies link=topic=361786.msg2750613#msg2750613 date=1239890184]
You should ask at http://ubuntuforums.org …

Cant you type startx? You should have shut down your laptop and then booted.
[/quote]
(I’ll ask at the ubuntu forums later if nobody here has a solution. Besides, what is the linux section for? :P)[/quote]Linux, not Ubuntu. I’ll just say RTFM to this one.

item.source: Turning off the GUI in Ubuntu Home

item.title: Turning off the GUI in Ubuntu Home
item.dc:creator: @Creme_de_la_Creme Creme de la Creme
item.description:
@Creme_de_la_Creme wrote:

[quote=“Fat Cookies, post:6, topic:273767”]You should ask at http://ubuntuforums.org …

Cant you type startx? You should have shut down your laptop and then booted. :([/quote]

Can’t type anything

I think the blank screen was just an idle thing because as I just grabbed the keyboard it showed them messages again (still unable to type). I pressed ctrl,alt,del to restart and as it was running the shutdown scripts it kept attempting to prompt me for a login username. This time it booted a lot faster though and didn’t show the “VIDEO MODE NOT SUPPORTED” at all, which is kinda good.

Tried CTRL+C to attempt to stop whatever its doing, no response. Pressed ESC, all the function keys, then hit a load of random keys and as a last resort tried to get the old beeping noise by holding a load of keys down - which also failed.

Is there any other combination I should try?

(I’ll ask at the ubuntu forums later if nobody here has a solution. Besides, what is the linux section for? :P)

Read full topic
item.source: Turning off the GUI in Ubuntu Home

item.description:
@Fat_Cookies wrote:

You should ask at http://ubuntuforums.org …

Cant you type startx? You should have shut down your laptop and then booted.

Read full topic
item.source: Turning off the GUI in Ubuntu Home

item.title: Turning off the GUI in Ubuntu Home
item.dc:creator: @Creme_de_la_Creme Creme de la Creme
item.description:
@Creme_de_la_Creme wrote:

Ughhh just had a mini heart attack… Unticked gdm from the services menu in hope I could try that command but it closed down gdm as soon as I unticked it. Luckily I guessed I could boot gdm by typing it lol.

I just tried the command after a restart (with gdm disabled) and it didn’t activate it. It doesn’t matter anyway, as long as I can get into the gui by typing gdm I can manually enable it myself, thanks :D[br][br][size=1]Posted on: April 16, 2009, 07:26:17 am[/size][hr]It’s gone a bit strange now. Last time I tried it on my laptop, now I just did it with the server and after rebooting its started to hate me.

First of all the monitor showed a message for a few minutes saying “VIDEO MODE NOT SUPPORTED” and it normally only does that for 30 seconds because it has trouble showing the load screen for some reason. Then it printed this:

Starting up...
Loading, please wait...
kinit: name_to_dev_t(/dev/disk/by-uuid/a791c6b2-4c0e-499b-9b54-d0503bb7e3d8) = da5(8,5)
kinit: trying to resume from /dev/disk/by-uuid/a791c6b2-4c0e-499b-9b54-d0503bb7e3d8
kinit: No resume image, doing normal boot...
_

I’m guessing that it’s a check ubuntu does on every boot to check for a hibernation file, but underneath the little blinkers just flashing as if it expects me to enter something or its loading, as “doing normal boot” suggests. It wont let me type anything in but all the server applications appear to be working fine and its been waiting for over 15 minutes

What could it actually be attempting to do and why is it taking forever? When I did this on my laptop it let me login and execute commands. On the server it automatically logged in as its set up to do and hasn’t given me a prompt. I’m going to need to execute a command sooner or later so how can I restore it without reinstalling?[br][br][size=1]Posted on: April 16, 2009, 07:27:04 am[/size][hr]And just as I posted that the screen went blank…

Read full topic
item.source: Turning off the GUI in Ubuntu Home

item.title: Turning off the GUI in Ubuntu Home
item.dc:creator: @Fat_Cookies Fat Cookies
item.description:
@Fat_Cookies wrote:

Im not perfectly sure (I would advise you to check):

sudo dpkg-reconfigure gdm

Read full topic

item.title: Turning off the GUI in Ubuntu Home
item.dc:creator: @Fat_Cookies Fat Cookies
item.description:
@Fat_Cookies wrote:

I think if you go into System, Administration and Services you can disable the Graphical Login Manager (gdm). I think that boots into cmd (I havnt tried it myself).

Read full topic

I’m going to install ubuntu server edition instead when I replace the hard disks with new ones in a few months, I just don’t want the downtime now because I’m new to linux and could take me days to set it up.
